posts.name:
Yurii Veremchuk
Yurii Veremchuk
posts.content:
Adding notes to connection requests is a bad idea.

(people accept such requests way less). Here's why:

1. Most notes are generic with no clear value.

“We share X connections”, “want to add you to my network”, "want to grow..."
If they accept the request -> those notes turn into DMs they must deal with.

2. People accept almost every connection request without a note.

- Yet a few accept every request with a note.
- In my personal experience, it's more effective to:

1. Send connection request without notes
2. Engage with the person's content a few times
3. No content? See if they comment on others' posts.
4. Wait for the opportunity to start a conversation in the DMs.

Unless…

3. You can add a highly customized note (personalized + relevant)

A note that can’t be copy+pasted to another person:

 “would love to add you to my network”
 Top-25 sales execs in 2024! Are you the first one from Woodpecker to do it?

Poor note = get ignored.
Amazing note = a conversation starter.

What’s your take on this topic?

PS. Struggling to write effective Cold Emails? DM me “COLD” and let's chat to see if we're a good fit to work together.

comments.commentText:
I sent a connection request with a note once.

Reason? I loved the person's content a lot.

What I wrote:

No sales pitch, just saying thank you. (Headline)

Hi ... (Then went ahead to appreciate what I loved about his content and how helpful it has been)


Will I write notes with connection requests again? Probably not, except I genuinely have something nice to say.

I agree with you
Timileyin Ayinde really? let's goooo!

When you have a message that hits prospects between the eyes (more like your ) AND you want to ramp up leads fast, adding a note in the connection request will save you days and weeks of being in the sales friend zone. Here's an example:

 "Thanks for liking my post. Here's a resource..."

 "I work exclusively with marketing leaders of fast-growth startups. Last month, we helped COMPANY drive 127 MQLs with cold email. Worth exploring?"

So it all depends on your goals and if you *actually* know what your prospects are struggling with...otherwise, even a blank connection request will still eventually result in no actual sales activity.
Ken Yarmosh love it, it must be super relevant. Then it works

Yurii Veremchuk I call it the Ultimate Outreach Message...once you nail it, you can scale this easily. 

(we arrive at that by clarifying the offer, then working backwards)

posts.name:
Haris Halkic
Haris Halkic
posts.content:
Most sellers:

• Dread cold calling.
• Avoid the phone.
• Fear rejection.

But too many never confront these fears.

They'll dodge calls, staying in their comfort zone.

They end up feeling stuck.

→ My advice to you: Don't fear cold calling - embrace it.

The only way to overcome this fear is through action.

Face your fears before they define you:

• Make that first call of the day, no matter how you feel.
• Share your journey with others to inspire and learn.
• Use rejections as stepping stones, not setbacks.
• Celebrate every small win to build confidence.
• Set a daily goal for cold calls and stick to it.

Don't let fear hold you back.

Here's a checklist you can use for cold calling:

𝟭. 𝗟𝗶𝘀𝘁 𝗽𝗿𝗲𝗽𝗮𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻

 Are your prospect details verified and up-to-date?

- thoroughly research your prospects
- focus on mobile numbers + mark verified numbers
- Use tools liketo enrich and verify your lead data.

𝟮. 𝗚𝗲𝘁 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱𝘆

 Are you mentally prepared and focused, ready to handle rejections positively?

Adopt this mindset:

"I approach each call as a new opportunity to learn and connect, keeping my objectives clear and staying adaptable throughout the conversation."

→ Each call is a win.

𝟯. 𝗗𝗶𝗮𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝘆

 Have you set up your workspace to maximize efficiency during your call sessions?

- Use dialers to organize your calls efficiently.
- Your CRM should give you the option to dial with one click.
- Open 30 tabs in your browser (=next calls)
- Time block 30-90minutes with regular 5min breaks
- Use times when you have the highest energy.

Is your focus on quantity or quality?

The truth is: you need both.

𝟰. 𝗢𝗽𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿

 Is it clear, concise, and does it feel natural to you?

It’s about finding what works for you.

Try it out at least 100 times before you move on.

Without giving your opener enough time to work, you’ll be lost.

𝟱. 𝗧𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆 & 𝗽𝗮𝗰𝗲

 Are you experimenting with trying different paces, volumes, and tones?
 Standing up or sitting upright to project confidence?
 Smiling while you speak?

Don’t forget: tonality and tempo are key. Work on this daily.

That doesn’t always mean being very upbeat.

A relaxed, friendly tone works well.

𝟲. 𝗔𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝗹𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴

 Are you responding to cues during the conversation?
 Are you using their information to ask deeper questions?

Make sure your solution can help - qualify them.

Don’t waste your time with interested non-buyers

Save the pitch for later meetings. Your only job: book the meeting.

𝟳. 𝗠𝗮𝗻𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗷𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻

 Have you accepted rejection as part of the game?

Each "No" you receive isn't personal - it's simply business.

Stay positive.

𝟴. 𝗥𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗿𝗱 𝗰𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗮𝗶𝗹𝘀

 Are you taking a moment to jot down everything?

Do it right after the call.

No matter how minor it may seem.

P.S. What's your best cold calling tip?

comments.commentText: well said—embrace the grind and make every call a step forward!

posts.name:
Shulin Lee
Shulin Lee
posts.content:
I used to work for a boss who loved to drink. 

And if you didn't join after-work drinks?

You'd get the side-eye, the next day. 

While my colleagues downed round after round,
I sipped tonic water (no gin), pretending to fit in.

My boss?
He thought I was all in with a G&T in hand.

The truth?
He was more interested in getting everyone drunk than building real connections.

That’s when I realized:
Workplace culture shouldn’t make you feel pressured to conform.

So, let’s debunk these 7 outdated myths about work:
(to build a high performing team )

Not Joining After-Work Drinks
↳ Doesn’t mean you’re not invested in the team.

Working Remotely
↳ Doesn’t mean you’re slacking off.

Having Passions Outside Work
↳ Doesn’t mean you’re not dedicated to your role.

Taking Parental Leave
↳ Doesn’t mean you’re taking a vacation.

Building A Purpose-Driven Business
↳ Doesn’t mean putting profits on the back burner.

Being Quiet In Meetings
↳ Doesn’t mean you lack ideas or impact.

Having Top-Notch Skills
↳ Doesn’t excuse a toxic attitude.

Handing Out Branded Swag
↳ Doesn’t mean you’ve built a winning culture.

Focus on outcomes,
not outdated assumptions.

That’s how you build teams that thrive. 

(thanks to my friend, for the graphics!)

️ Repost to help others debunk outdated work myths
 And followfor more!

P.S. I partied hard in my 20s.

P.P.S. Just not with colleagues, and certainly not with my ex-boss!

comments.commentText: One word - TRUST - flows through all the slides - how to build it in teams and organizations, knowing that at every point, wherever they are, they have the best interest of the team and the organization at heart. Knowing, understanding and deploying the building blocks of TRUST. This is the same problem with finding a balance between having employees report to an office and remote work. The same problem that pushes us to micro-manage employees, and direct reports, instead of providing leadership.

George . Trust is the foundation of any strong team and organization. If teams feel trusted, they’ll naturally perform better, whether in the office or remote. 

It’s all about empowering people, not micromanaging.

Leadership is about guidance, not control!
Shulin Lee Absolutely. Building a culture of trust is key.

Shulin Lee so true. Wearing a "work persona" mask is exhausting - it's like running a background program that constantly drains your energy. When you're busy trying to fit someone else's mold, you're using creativity and mental space that could be spent on actual innovation and growth.
The best work environments aren't just about what you do - they're about giving you the psychological safety to be who you are. When you can bring your authentic self to work, your natural talents and unique perspectives naturally shine through.
Life's too short for professional pretense. Thanks for sharing.
Cyber Trust So well said! It's exhausting to wear a mask. When you're free to be yourself, that’s when the magic happens. Authenticity fuels creativity and innovation!

posts.name:
Sally Mildren
Sally Mildren
posts.content:
I have been "off" social mostly for about a month while I was ill and out for the holiday. During that time, I have observed the feeds, convos, etc. and I remain committed to these truths and these practices in my own work:

 I will continue to focus on helping business owners and nonprofits to simplify their approach to marketing. More is not the answer, clarity is.

 I will continue my commitment to educating and helping marketing leaders grow in their craft and leadership. Doing marketing stuff does not equal strategy. It's so easy to get distracted and work on the well meaning, wrong things.

 I will not engage in energy vampire conversations that are designed to just promote argument, hatred, unkindness, or bull. I don't have time or interest in dogma over humans. If you persist, I will easily block from my feeds.

 Business at all cost is not success at all. For those that sent me (automated or not) pitches on Christmas Day, you were removed from my inbox. When I saw a post from our agency go up on Christmas Day I was really embarassed and determined to never let that happen again. Rest is sacred. People need time off. Just stop and honor rest. I will too.

 Not all content is helpful or necessary. Less is better than fluff.

What would you add?

comments.commentText: ALL OF THIS . Especially to humans over dogma and more consciousness in business. We are with you

posts.name:
Michael Kainatsky
Michael Kainatsky
posts.content:
We all make way too many excuses. 


Let’s just be honest with ourselves.

We are too comfortable in our situations for most of our lives.

That’s why we often make excuses.

Excuses are only options until you don’t have the luxury of that choice.

There are many complicated hacks.

But there’s one simple one.

Just live as though you don’t have a choice.

Lying to others is no where near as bad as lying to yourself.

They may never know the truth, but you will always know.

A man I greatly respect once said something that still stays with me.

“Excuses become valid reasons for failure

when we fail to execute the plan.”

Yours truthfully,

comments.commentText:
Michael The greatest lies we tell are to ourselves. Also if we are making excuses and not doing the things we say we want to do, my first step is to get curious and explore why. 

For example, sometimes when a clients says they want to do something but they arent taking action, I discover that its not what they truly want (rather its based on what they think they SHOULD do). If they do truly want it then inaction can be down to various (programmed) resistances/blocks which can be addressed ️
Laura you always offer such clear and actionable insights.
Michael Kainatsky I do my best
If I keep having an excuse to do something- I will sit down and reevaluate- why? Maybe I truly don’t want to do something that makes me to have excuses…
Marina we don’t always have the luxury of wanting to do something. Sometimes we just must.

 “𝐄𝐥𝐞𝐯𝐚𝐭𝐞” 𝐛𝐲&.

 𝐋𝐢𝐟𝐞: Empower yourself by taking control of your journey and aligning your actions with your values.
 𝐋𝐞𝐚𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐡𝐢𝐩: Lead with authenticity and purpose, whether you're a CEO, an entrepreneur, or simply striving to influence and inspire.
 𝐋𝐨𝐧𝐠𝐞𝐯𝐢𝐭𝐲: Prioritize well-being to achieve balance, prevent burnout, and sustain long-term success.

 It combines CEO-level insights with life-coaching wisdom.

posts.name:
Eleni Georgiou
Eleni Georgiou
posts.content:
I saw a recent post regarding salaries and thought this was a great piece of information to share as I frequently speak to Consultants who mainly aim to receive higher salaries.

Understandably a higher salary can certainly be appealing, but it’s not the only factor that leads to happiness or fulfillment. Here’s why:



𝐖𝐨𝐫𝐤-𝐋𝐢𝐟𝐞 𝐁𝐚𝐥𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐌𝐚𝐭𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐬: A high salary can come with long hours, stress, and burnout. Prioritizing work-life balance and spending time with family or pursuing hobbies is vital for mental and physical well-being.

𝐉𝐨𝐛 𝐒𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐬𝐟𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧: Doing work you love or can bring a sense of purpose, even if the paycheck isn’t as big. Feeling fulfilled in your role and having a sense of contribution can outweigh financial rewards. In addition to this, a higher salary will comes with more expectations, whereas starting on a lower salary with room for you to enhance your base and commission will buy you time to build your knowledge.

𝐇𝐞𝐚𝐥𝐭𝐡 & 𝐒𝐭𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐬: A job that is less demanding on your time and energy often leads to better overall health. High-paying positions sometimes come with high stress levels, which can have a detrimental impact on your well-being in the long run.

𝐏𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐨𝐧𝐚𝐥 𝐆𝐫𝐨𝐰𝐭𝐡: Sometimes the best opportunities for growth come from taking risks, learning new skills, and challenging yourself in areas beyond money. A position that offers personal development can be just as valuable as financial compensation.


𝐈𝐟 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐝 𝐢𝐧 𝐝𝐢𝐬𝐜𝐮𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐰𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐥𝐨𝐧𝐠 𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐦 𝐠𝐨𝐚𝐥𝐬 𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐰𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐝 𝐟𝐫𝐨𝐦 𝐚 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐚𝐧𝐲 𝐭𝐨 𝐛𝐞 𝐚𝐛𝐥𝐞 𝐭𝐨 𝐚𝐜𝐡𝐢𝐞𝐯𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐬, 𝐥𝐞𝐭'𝐬 𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐧𝐞𝐜𝐭!

comments.commentText: ... and the cost of the commute!

posts.name:
Saurabh Tandon
Saurabh Tandon
posts.content:
Our biggest wins often start with cutting our losses!

We’ve all been there —

Pouring time, energy, and money into something,

only to realize it’s just not working.

But we keep holding on.



Why?

Because we’re too invested to let go.



Here’s the hard truth:

The longer we cling, the more we lose.



Therefore, I did some thinking

and curated a list of things

I’m guilty of ‘overvaluing’:



↳ That underperforming stock I researched for months

↳ Business ideas I clung to despite zero results

↳ A Netflix show I don’t enjoy but feel I must finish

↳ Marketing campaigns with poor ROI I kept running

↳ A hire who’s not aligned, but I hold on to

↳ Books, podcasts, courses hard to abandon

↳ Relationships that drain more than they enrich

↳ CRMs I spent months building, now outdated️

↳ Staying in a job out of loyalty, despite no excitement



Sound familiar?

This behavior has a name: sunk cost fallacy.

We keep pouring into something

because we’ve already poured so much in.



But here’s the thing:

The more time we waste on suboptimal choices,

the less time we have for better ones.



So, what’s the solution?

 Ask yourself:

If I hadn’t already invested in this,

would I start it today?



 Focus on opportunity cost:

What am I giving up by sticking to this?



 Let go faster.

The quicker you cut your losses,

the sooner you can redirect your energy.



Letting go isn’t quitting.

It’s creating space for what truly matters.



What’s one thing you’ve been holding on to

that you know it’s time to leave behind?

 Share your story in the comments.

You might inspire someone else to let go too.

comments.commentText:

Ask yourself:

- Would I start this today?
- What’s it costing me to stay?

Letting go isn’t quitting.
It’s making room for what truly matters.
Christopher Angiolillo awesome ! Biggest loss in this case is the loss of time which prevents us from turnaround as well
